data.text: Any of various nonplacental mammals of the infraclass Metatheria, including kangaroos, opossums, bandicoots, and wombats, found principally in Australia and the Americas, and typically bearing young that suckle and develop after birth in the mother's pouch. These species were formerly placed in the order Marsupialia.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Of or belonging to the infraclass Metatheria.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Relating to or having a marsupium.
data.attributionText: from The American Heritage® Dictionary of the English Language, 5th Edition.

data.text: Having the character of a bag, pouch, or marsupium; marsupiate.
Of or pertaining to a marsupium: as, marsupial bones.
Provided with a marsupium; specifically, pertaining to the Marsupialia, or having their characters.
A member of the order Marsupialia; any implacental didelphian mammal. Also called marsupiate.
Having a pouch for carrying the immature young; of or pertaining to the Marsupialia.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.

data.text: Of or pertaining to a marsupium.
data.attributionText: from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
from the GNU version of the Collaborative International Dictionary of English.
